content.description: Just kidding about the X! This is a good crack to send the kids up, give beginners a chance to 'top out' on a crack. Might be easier than 5.3, but hey, it's there.
content.location: The farthest right line at the crag.

content.description: Opposite of The Cardiac Arete is the only other arete at the crag, this one not bolted. Start directly below and slightly to the right of the overhanging arete, move up into a good jug, move  up on thin fingers and step out onto the arete proper. Could be a 5.12 move or two, who knows?

climbs.name: The Ish or the Er. aka French Fried Frog Legs

content.description: The widest section wall, all of 8'. Named Ish or Er as in 10ish or 5.10er. Easy to make it 5.8, contrived to stay in the 10ish sections.
content.location: TO the right of the arete, 5 bolts contrive their way 30' up to chains.

content.description:
The roadside crag has been "discovered" by numerous parties, some before bolting, some after. But until Paul Bernard's great book "Rock climbs of Northeast California" few knew of names of routes or FA's in the area. Hence many names for the same route.

French Fried Knuckle Buster is a case in point. A few un-named guys got together and did all the lines here, naming everything "French Fried....". No one remembers  why, just happened.

The line goes straight up through 3 mini roofs, with at least 2 dynos and as many lock off dead points. Named for the busted knuckles you might get if you blow the last big dyno. He did.
content.location: Center of the "First Pillar". Best to extend the chains a little with a runner, draws, etc.

climbs.name: First Pillar
climbs.fa: Sean and Ian Baxter, Kevin Penland

content.description: As you enter the area the first 'climb on your left. "First  Pillar" has at least 3 top rope lines on it, variations and distinct. Fun place to play.
content.location: The first tall section of rock on the left as you come into the crag. The chains are easily accessed either from the road side or up easy 5th just to the left of First Pillar.

content.description:
Another one of those..."if this was a whole pitch it would be awesome" lines.

Start low to the left of the arete, following the diagonal crack to where you can pull up onto the center of the face, move up, not using the crack to your right. Contrived, but fun. The crux is finding the mono, which on the first ascent was hidden by spider webs. Good practice for small edges.
content.location: The face to the right of Muscrat Love. Chains on top.

content.description: To the right of 'The Corner' is The Crack. A face with a zigzag crack.
content.location: The face to the right of the dark mossy corner has a crack. Start on the left or right. Finish in the corner.

climbs.name: The Corner
climbs.fa: Aaron Smith, Sean and Ian Baxter, Kevin Penland

content.description: The big dark wide mossy corner. If that sounds appealing, go for it. Lots of options to play on.
content.location: To the right of First Pillar. The only dark, wide mossy corner here. You can use the chains from either First Pillar or Cardiac Arete.

content.description: If this was a full pitch, it would rate 4 stars. A fun, challenging line right off the ground to the top. Groundfall potential on the first 2 bolts. The only bolted arete on the central "pillar", right of the Corner.
content.location: The prominent arete in the middle of the crag. You can lower or walk off.

content.description: (From Paul Bernard's book) Chain anchor serves as toprope for a number of possible lines on the third pillar. The main face involves a thumb hook and the arete on the left has at least a couple of 5.12 moves.
content.location: The third pillar. Rap from chains, or walk off left.
